CreditLine: Acquired by Henry Walters with the Massarenti Collection, 1902
Description:
The cycle of the seasons fascinated 17th-century Europeans, but the shifts in the tilt of the earth that causes them were not understood. Winter was especially hard then; Europe was in the middle of a little ice age and it was much colder than today. The Southern Netherlands was also in the midst of a war, and ill-paid soldiers terrorized the peasants.

Here, the landscapist de Momper uses subdued color and tonal unity to suggest the bleakness of a late winter afternoon, complemented by an intricate, stark pattern of barren branches against the sky.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: New Light on Old Pictures: Dutch and Flemish Paintings from the Walters
Exhibitions.Textblock: New Light on Old Pictures: Dutch and Flemish Paintings from the Walters. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1981-1982.

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Charles Street: Second Floor: Chamber of Wonders

Provenance: Don Marcello Massarenti Collection, Rome [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1902, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Winter Landscape
